bioghist.p: The Armenian Studies Program at the University of Michigan began in 1976 with the introduction of courses in Armenian language and history. In 1981, the Alex Manoogian Chair in Modern Armenian History was established. A second chair, the Marie Manoogian Chair in Armenian Language and Literature, was established in 1987. Both chairs were funded the Alex and Marie Manoogian Foundation.

The Armenian Studies Program features a vigorous outreach program to involve Armenians of Southeastern Michigan and the Midwest in its educational activities, periodic lectures, and films. The program publishes a yearly newsletter, develops cultural programs and the Summer Language Institute, an intensive six-week course on Armenian language held at Yerevan State University in Armenia. Courses focus on Armenian language, history, architecture, literature, and intellectual history. The Armenian Studies Program is affiliated with the International Institute and involves faculty from several different departments, centers, and programs across campus.
As of September 2003, current information on the Armenian Studies Program can be found on the Web at the following URL: http://www.umich.edu/~iinet/asp/

scopecontent.p: The records of the Armenian Studies Program document the history of the program from 1983 to 2003. The records are divided into two series: Administrative and Events and Publications.

scopecontent.p: The Administrative series, 1983-2003 (0.10 linear feet), contains minutes of Armenian Studies Program committee meetings. The minutes of these committee meetings discuss the current status and future objectives of the program. Of particular note is the agreement that the University of Michigan has with Yerevan State University for the Summer Language Institute.

scopecontent.p: The Events and Publications series, 1983-2003 (0.15 linear feet), documents the social and intellectual activities developed to celebrate and study Armenian history and culture. Included is publicity and background on events sponsored by the Armenian Studies Program. A chronological list of events and speakers is located in the first events folder. The records also contain a CD-ROM of an exhibition of Armenian Rugs held in 1983. Also included in this series is the newsletter of the Armenian Studies Program, which gives a yearly account of activities and scholarship in the program.
